title: Noosa developer strikes deal to buy Great Keppel Island
text:
A spokesman for the Queensland Department of Natural Resources, Mines and Energy (DNRME) told The Australian Financial Review it had received an application to transfer the leases associated with the development on Great Keppel Island.

"As part of the assessment, DNRME considers whether an incoming lessee is capable of meeting the development requirements detailed in the leases," the spokesman said.

"DNRME is currently awaiting necessary information from Altum Properties Pty Ltd to enable this process to commence."

Great Keppel Island, which lies 12 kilometres from coast of Yeppoon, has approval for a major development including a 250-room hotel, 750 eco-tourism villas, 300 eco-tourism apartments, 250-berth marina and ferry terminal.

"The Queensland government has committed $30 million for common-user power and water infrastructure connections to Great Keppel Island to help support tourism operators," the spokesman said.

It is understood the new buyers have negotiated a longer settlement period than that struck with Wei Chao.

Bill Ludwig, Mayor of Livingstone Shire Council under which Great Keppel Island falls, told the Financial Review he had met with the potential new buyers about six weeks ago.

Advertisement

"They have considerable development experience and it felt positive. Developing Great Keppel Island is key to the region's tourism future," Mr Ludwig said.

"All the approvals are in place, but it needs someone to invest in and then activate the island. We are very keen to see it resolved."

However, Altum's ability to develop a circa-$400 million resort has already been questioned by local groups, given it has to date only developed apartments, townhouse and residential estates and has no experience in delivering tourism projects.

The previous decaying resort on the island was demolished last year to make way for the new development.

During the 1990s, Great Keppel was a famed party destination known by the slogan "Get Wrecked on Keppel".

Mr Agnew's Tower Holding's paid $16.5 million in 2008 for the island before shutting it down and unveiling plans for a $2.5 billion luxury resort shortly afterwards.

However, numerous previous attempts to sell it proved unsuccessful.
description: Altum Property Group has exchanged contracts to acquire the leasehold but is awaiting approval from the Queensland government.
